questions.text: Which statement about the maximal permitted AC voltage in LV systems is false?

solution.text:
Maximum permitted AC voltage is 50V RMS (root median square)
 So the maximum peak voltage is 50*sqr(2)=70.71 (A is true [After Protest: is false])
 Which is greater than the maximum DC (60V) (D is true)

 The maximum average voltage is RMS/1.1111 = 45 V (C is false)

questions.text:
A vehicle is taking part in the Acceleration Event. Just before braking, the vehicle is traveling at 105 kph. Assume that the braking force per axle is 2.1kN.

Calculate the greatest static F force in the rope during a tilt-test procedure\n What is the minimum load capacity if a 1.35 safety factor is implemented?\n (g is 10m/s^2, weight of the car is 240 kg)

solution.text:
The greatest load is at the starting, when the angle between the table and the ground is 0, so every data is on the picture, no need for trigonometrics/Pithagoras/CoG height.
 The torque at the turning point from the car’s mass:
 M = 1.2m ∗ 2400N = 2880Nm
 Static force, the torque by the car’s mass and the torque by the forc are equal:
 F = 2880Nm/2m = 1440N
 Implementing a safety factor of 1.35:
 F(capacity) = 1440N ∗ 1.35 = 1944N
 Which is the closest, but smaller to 2000N

questions.text:
A chocolate manufacturer is producing a new type of chocolate bar with a special formulation. The chocolate is initially melted and poured into a mould at a temperature of 50°C. The chocolate bar is then left to cool in a room with a constant temperature of 20°C. The manufacturer wants to determine the time it takes for the chocolate to cool down to a safe handling temperature of 30°C.
 Given that the chocolate follows Newton's Law of Cooling, the manufacturer has conducted preliminary experiments and determined that the cooling rate constant (k) for this chocolate formulation is 0.02 per minute.
 Determine the time it takes for the chocolate to cool down from 50°C to 30°C.
 Answer in min and provide the value with 2 decimal places, e.g. 12.34.

solution.text:
Newton’s Law of Cooling: dTdt=k(T-T amb)\n
T amb=20°C\n
so T(t) = 20 + 30e-0.02t\n
solving for t with T(t)=30°C gives t = - ln(13)0.02 = 54.93 min

questions.text: Knowing that the member AC is under a force of -25 kN, what is the force in the element HG? Force R is an unknown horizontal force applied on point H.\n Answer in kN and provide the value with 1 decimal place, e.g. 12.3.\n Follow the sign convention “-” for a compressive force and “+” for tensile, e.g. -12.3 or 12.3.

solution.text:
Assuming positive x from left to right and positive y from down to up (coordinate system not relevant for solution)\n
R_A_x (x component of reactive force at A) = -f_AC = 25 kN\n
Sum of forces along x:\n
R_A_x = sin(45)*100 kN - R => R = 45.71068 kN\n
Sum of moments around A\n
R_G_y * 12 = 25 * 3 + R * 3 + 100 * sin(45) *9 - 100 * cos(45) *6 => R_G_y = 35.355 kN\n
R_G_y = - f_HG => f_HG = -35.355 kN

What is the static longitudinal weight distribution of the car? \n (Assume that the vehicle is coasting, i.e., no longitudinal force is applied by the wheels on the ground).\n Answer as % of mass on the front axle and provide the value with 1 decimal place, e.g. 12.3.

solution.text:
Question 3 was later deleted because wording 



Front wheel rate = Front spring stiffness / front motion ratio = 16 / 0.8 ^ 2 = 25 N/mm

Rear wheel rate = Rear spring stiffness / rear motion ratio = 18 / 0.75 ^ 2 = 32 N/mm


Note that the drag force does not cause any longitudinal mass transfer since it is not balanced by an equal and opposite force applied in the tires, i.e., the drag force causes deceleration of the vehicle instead of mass transfer.

questions.text: The figure below depicts an Improved Howland Current Pump circuit. Assume that Vin- is connected to ground, 0 V, and Vin  is 5 V. For R1 = R2 = R3 = 1 kΩ and R4 = 100 Ω, compute the magnitude of the output current Iout.\n Answer in mA and provide the value with 1 decimal place, e.g. 12.3.

solution.text:
Formulas for an improved howland pump circuit:\n
Iout = (G × (Vin + − Vin −))/R4,\n
G = R3/R1; R3/R1 = (R5 + R4)/R3\n
G = 1k/1k = 1; 1 = (R5 + R4)/R3 <=> R5 = 1000 − 100 = 900 Ω\n
Iout = 1 * (5 − 0)/100 = 0. 05 A = 50. 0 mA

The engineer considers two materials for the panel: aluminium and quasi-isotropic carbon fibre. The aluminium used has a Young’s Modulus of 70GPa and a density of 2.7 g/cm^3. The composite used has a Young’s Modulus of 220 GPa and a density of 1.26 g/cm^3. The environmental impact of the beam aluminium used is 8 kgCO2 per kilo of aluminium and the one of the carbon is 26 kgCO2 per kilo of composite. What is the lowest possible CO2 emission out of these two options while having a beam maximum deflection of 3 mm. a) Aluminium \nb) Composite Answer in kgCO2 and provide the value with 3 decimal places, e.g. 12.345.

Your racecar is performing a steady-state corner with 8 metres radius at a speed of 10.2 m/s. The vehicle has a longitudinal weight distribution of 50% front / 50% rear, parallel steering (0% ackermann), and 0.5 degrees rear wheel toe in. Knowing that the slip angle of the rear inside wheel is 4.6 degrees, how much toe is needed on the front wheels to ensure that these have equal slip angles (αfi = αfo)? \n lf = 0.8 m, lr = 0.8m, t = 1.2 m, δ = 12 deg \n Toe in is considered positive, toe out is considered negative. Answer in deg and provide the value with 1 decimal place, e.g. 12.3.

solution.text:
Assuming x is positive from rear to front and y is positive from right to left (coordinate system not relevant for solution)\n
Yaw_rate = velocity/radius = 10.2 / 8 = 1.275 rad/s\n
Vx_RI = Vx - Yaw_rate*t/2 = 9.435 m/s\n
Vy_RI = -tan(alfa_RI + toe_rear)*Vx_RI = -tan(5.1 deg)*9.435 = 0.84205 m/s\n
Vx_FI = Vx_RI = 9.435 m/s\n
Vy_FI = Vy_RI + Yaw_rate * (lr+lf) = -tan(5.1 deg)*9.435 + 1.275*1.6 = 1.19795 m/s\n
alfa_FI = 12 - atan(1.19795/9.435) - toe_front = 4.76 - toe_front\n
Vx_FO = Vx + Yaw_rate*t/2 = 10.965 m/s\n
Vy_FO = Vy_FI = 1.19795 m/s\n
alfa_FO = 12 - atan(1.19795/10.965) + toe_front = 5.76 + toe_front\n
alfa_FI = alfa_FO => toe_front = - 0.5 deg

questions.text:
You run with Formula student car 2 skid pad runs. For the second run, you use modified suspension pickup points to put the front roll centre higher. In both cases you run in a perfectly steady state, with the same path, speed, lateral acceleration (let's say 1 [g]) and you get the same time.
- 1st run front roll centre height = 50 [mm] (above the ground)
- 2nd run front roll centre height = 100 [mm] (above the ground)
- Rear roll centre height = 100 [mm] (above the ground)
- Front and rear track are the same = 1000 [mm]
- Suspended mass centre of gravity height = 250 [mm] (above the ground)
You run front and rear double wishbone suspensions setup without any ARBs, just a single coilover with a linear spring on every corner. You move the front roll centre higher, by moving the wishbones and steering rack pickup points higher on the chassis.
We assume that:
- roll centre positions are static - they do not change when the car rolls,
- we do not take into account aerodynamic forces, tires deflection and race track is perfectly flat, non suspended mass and tires Mx are negligibly low (x is assumed as longitudinal axis).
- the car is symmetric, 50% front weight distribution, all motion ratios = 1, all spring stiffnesses are the same, 4 wheels are on the ground, coilovers do not reach their travel limit,
- the caster and KPI angle are equal 0, so we do not take into account any steer jacking,
- for the second run we do not change the centre gravity position, spring rates or motion ratios when changing the front roll centre height. The alignment, camber gain, bump steer, tires, track, wheelbase - all stays the same.
On the front coilovers you run linear potentiometers. They read 0 when the car drives straight on a flat surface. We assume that they read the displacement as the absolute value. This means that no matter if the coilover is being compressed or extended, it gives positive value. You read with them 4 values:
- L1 - Front left coilover displacement on the first run
- R1 - Front right coilover displacement on the first run
- L2 - Front left coilover displacement on the second run
- R2 - Front right coilover displacement on the second run

We are considering left hand corner, so left coilover potentiometers are being extended and right ones are being shortened.

questions.text:
As a new team member, you’ve been given the following exercise. For next year’s project, we are planning to use one dual piston (one on each side) caliper for each one of the two rear brakes. We already have a caliper in mind and we want you to double-check our choice.

Some reminders and simplifying considerations:
